attributes.title: The effect of ESM on the participants’ emotional awareness
attributes.description: Frequent measurements direct participants to become aware, label and report their emotional experiences multiple times a day. Repeatedly directing attention to one’s inner state has previously been shown to increase trait mindfulness and emotional differentiation, constructs which are conceptually greatly overlapping with emotional awareness. The question that we propose in this study is whether repeated measures of ESM similarly increase participants’ emotional awareness over time and if this increase is related to the sampling frequency. Our goal is to analyze how the participation in ESM affects emotional awareness of the participants.  To this end, 164 participants were randomly assigned to receive questionnaires 3, 6, or 9 times per day over 14 days. Different measures will be used to study within-subject changes in trait and momentary emotional awareness over time, as well as to compare these changes between the different conditions.

q1.value: Mariam Chichua, Gudrun Eisele, Peter Kuppens, Peter Kuppens

q2.value:
I.	Trait emotional awareness
a.	Within person: higher trait emotional awareness in the post-test compared to the pre-test
b.	Between persons: the increase between pre- and post-tests is bigger in higher sampling frequency groups
II.	Daily emotional awareness
a.	Within person: increase of momentary emotional awareness over the period of 14 days
b.	Between persons: higher increase in momentary emotional awareness with higher sampling frequency

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Participants did not know the intervention group to which they had been assigned. At the beginning of the study, participants did know that there were groups that differ in the amount of time they need to invest and in the incentive they receive (this was stated on the informed consent), but they were not informed about the nature of the other groups.

question.value:
All study procedures have been approved by the Social and Societal Ethics Committee at KU Leuven. A baseline session was followed by a 14 day ESM period. After the ESM period participants returned to the lab for a follow-up session. The individual parts of the study are described in the following paragraphs in more detail.

Baseline session
After providing informed consent, participants were randomly assigned to one of the six experimental conditions and asked to fill out the baseline questionnaires (trait emotional awareness, previous or current psychopathology, alcohol use, smoking, drug use, demographics & contact information, smartphone use, personality, depression, anxiety, self-esteem, emotion regulation, perceived stress, & momentary and trait affect). The six conditions were: a short ESM questionnaire 3 times per day, a short ESM questionnaire 6 times per day, a short ESM questionnaire 9 times per day, a long ESM questionnaire 3 times per day, a long ESM questionnaire 6 times per day, a long ESM questionnaire 9 times per day. The short questionnaire consisted of ± 30 items (depending on branching logic) and the long questionnaire consisted of ± 60 items (depending on branching logic). All participants were tested on trait emotional awareness (Neumann et al., 2010). Participants were briefed individually about the ESM testing period and practiced filling in the ESM questionnaire to assure that all items were understood by the participants. The briefing lasted approximately 20 minutes. As determined by the randomization procedure, participants were also told how many times per day they would be signaled to complete the questionnaire and how much money they would receive for their participation (the incentive was dependent on the condition; participants in the conditions with 3 beeps per day received 40 euro, while those in the 6 and 9 beep conditions received 60 and 80 euro, respectively). The briefing was conducted in Dutch or English, depending on the researcher conducting the session.


14 Days of ESM
The lab visit was followed by the ESM testing period of 14 days. During this time, participants, depending on the experimental condition, received 3, 6, or 9 prompts per day to fill in a short or long questionnaire. Participants had the option to contact the researchers in case of problems.

Posttest session
After the two weeks of ESM, a second session was conducted during which participants were asked to fill out the posttest questionnaires (emotional awareness, burden, social norm & ideal affect, depression, anxiety, self-esteem, emotion regulation, momentary and retrospective affect). A (randomly chosen) subsample of 10 participants per experimental condition was invited to a qualitative interview lasting approximately 10 minutes, at the end of the posttest session. The qualitative interview was semi-structured, in the sense that participants were asked a series of predetermined questions and follow-up questions were asked depending on the answers. All participants received their compensation and were debriefed about the study after the posttest session. During the debriefing, it was explained that the study consisted of different groups that received different numbers of beeps per day and different questionnaires. Participants received 40, 60, or 80 euro in form of gift vouchers depending on the number of beeps per day. The amounts of the incentives were decided during focus groups and based on experiences of researchers with student recruitment at KU Leuven in the past, as well as the available budget. We reduced the incentive to 25, 30, and 40 euro if a participant responded to less than a third of the scheduled beeps during the study (i.e., to less than 14, 28, and 42 beeps in the 3, 6, and 9 beep conditions, respectively). The reduced amount corresponds to the full payment for both lab sessions (20 euro) plus roughly a third of the payment for the ESM period (no exact payments were possible because the payments needed to be made in vouchers of 5 euro). Participants were informed about the existence of a minimum compliance requirement during the briefing, but not about the exact requirement (this sentence was used in the briefing: “If we find that you didn’t fill in enough beeps, you will not get the full payment at the end.”).

q7.value: A total of 164 participant were randomly assigned to an experimental condition. Randomization into the different conditions was based on a scheme that ensured that an equal number of participants in each condition started on every day of the week (participants could start on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday). This measure was taken to prevent that time effects would be driven by weekday (e.g., if all participants in one group would start on a Tuesday, a drop of compliance on the 5th ESM day could be purely driven by the fact that the 5th ESM day was always a Saturday; starting a roughly equal number of participants from every condition on every weekday was supposed to assure that these effects cancel out). Ten participants per experimental condition were randomly selected to take part in the qualitative interview.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: As of the date of submission, the data exist and G.E. has accessed it, parts of the data has already been used for the analysis of another research question (Eisele et al., 2020). The ESM study includes a large number of variables, which will be used to answer different research questions by researchers within the same team.

question.value:
Participants were eligible for inclusion if they were Dutch speaking, between 18-30 years old, currently enrolled as a student at a university or hogeschool, and had never taken part in a study that used a phone app before. Participants were recruited via advertisements on Facebook groups for research participants and flyers that were placed on different campuses of KU Leuven and in local bars. Recruitment started on 17.12.18 and testing was conducted between 11.02.19 and 18.07.19.

Of the 164 participants that took part in the baseline session, 3 participants had to be excluded because they were not currently enrolled as a student, 2 dropped out during the ESM period, 4 missed more than 1 full day of data because of technical problems (for one participant the battery of the phone broke, for 3 people the time of the phone was reset for unknown reasons which led to beeps not being delivered), for 2 participants the time on the phone was off by more than 1 hour (which lead to the beeps being delivered at wrong times), and 1 participant failed to meet the minimum compliance requirement of one third of the ESM questionnaires started. For all these participants new participants were recruited. The reasoning for this decision was to assure that we would have at least 25 participants per condition in all analyses. Since it was uncertain whether technical problems would appear or participants would complete the study, more participants were included than our original inclusion goal. As soon as it was clear that every group had 25 ‘valid’ cases, no further participants were recruited.

ESM data collection procedure: 
The ESM period lasted 14 days and was signal contingent. Participants received 3, 6, or 9 beeps, depending on the condition they have been assigned to during the baseline session. Beeps were semi-randomly spread between 9 am and 10:30 pm. In the 3-beep condition, beeps were scheduled randomly in each of three 4 h 30 min windows. In the 6-beep condition, the day was split into six 2 h 15 min windows and a beep was scheduled randomly in each of the windows. In the 9-beep condition, the day was split into 9 1h 30 min windows and one beep scheduled in each of them. There was a no beep window of 20 minutes between consecutive beeps.

On day 3, 6, 9, and 12, an instructed response item (i.e., a trick item that was supposed to function as a test if participants were paying attention to the questionnaire) was added to one of the questionnaires. It was always presented at the middle beep in the 3 beep condition and switched between the third and fourth beep in the 6 beep condition. In the 9 beep condition, it was shown once at the fourth beep, once at the sixth beep, and twice at the fifth beep. Due to constraints by the program used, no no-beep window of 20 minutes could be guaranteed between the last beep before the questionnaire with the instructed response item and the questionnaire with instructed response item (i.e., the last beep before the beep with the instructed response item could be less than 20 minutes before the beep with the instructed response item). The same applies to the first questionnaire after the questionnaire with the instructed response item.

Participants were randomly assigned to receive either a short (~30 items) or long questionnaire (~60 items) during the study. Following a pilot test, we estimated the completion time for the short questionnaire to be around 1,5 min and 2,5 min for the long questionnaire. The phone beeped or vibrated for 90 seconds or until the participant started filling in the questionnaire. After 90 seconds, the questionnaire became unavailable. Once participants started filling in the questionnaire, they had 90 seconds until time out per question (in case of time out, the questionnaire stopped and no subsequent questions were shown). Participants received a phone (motorola DEFY+) with the app mobileQ (Meers et al., 2019) installed on it. Other functions of the phone were fully disabled. At every beep, a start screen of the questionnaire was displayed automatically. Participants had to press “start survey” on this start screen to proceed to the first question. Sound and vibration could be turned on and off separately by the participants, but they couldn’t be disabled at the same time (if sound was switched off, the vibration was turned on automatically). Notifications did not require an internet connection to be delivered.

q11.value: A total of 150 (25 participants per group) participants were recruited for the study.

q12.value: Based on the power calculations done for another research question (Eisele et al., 2020), a sample of 25 participants per group was deemed sufficient, adding up to a total of 150 participants. We estimated power using a Monte Carlo based simulation approach to compare compliance between the groups. The power analysis was focused on the two main effects of interest (beep frequency and questionnaire length) and assume average compliance rates of 80%, 70%, and 60% for the 3, 6, and 9-beep conditions for the short version of the questionnaire and 70%, 60%, and 50% for the long version of the questionnaire (and standard deviations of 1.0 and 0.6 for the between-person and between-day logit-transformed compliance proportions). Based on the simulated conditions, power was 98% for the beep frequency and 76% for the questionnaire length effect. Power might be lower for other analyses.

q13.value: We sampled participants until we had data of at least 150 subjects without pervasive technical problems (pervasive defined as leading to more than 1 day of missing beeps).

question.value:
We manipulated sampling frequency, which resulted in 3 different conditions: participants receiving questionnaires 3, 6, or 9 times per day.

We manipulated questionnaire length as well, however it is not investigated in this proposal.

Measured non-ESM/time invariant variables

- Trait emotional awareness (Neumann et al., 2010)


	Measured ESM/time-variant variables

 -	Momentary emotional awareness
	“Op dit moment ben ik me bewust van mijn emoties”.
(Right now, I am aware of my feelings)
	“Ik vind het moeilijk om in een cijfer weer te geven hoe ik me voel.”
(I find it difficult to indicate in a number how I am feeling)

Time invariant
	Trait emotional awareness will be assessed by taking the mean of the items representing emotional awareness in baseline and follow-up tests. 
	Sampling Frequency:
	A 3-level factor will be used to indicate the sampling frequency with level 1 for the 3 beeps group, level 2 for the 6 beeps, and level 3 for 9 beeps per day.

	Time varying
	Momentary emotional awareness at a single beep will be measured by taking the mean of the two items representing the opposite of emotional awareness at every beep. 
	Day number is defined as the day of the ESM testing period, starting at 0 and going until 13.

Statistical models

I.	Trait emotional awareness 
a.	Within person: higher trait emotional awareness in the post-test compared to the pre-test 
Analysis: Repeated measures ANOVA
Dependent variable: Mean of the subscale emotional awareness
Predictor: Time
b.	Between persons: the increase between pre and post tests is higher in higher frequency groups
Analysis: Repeated measures ANOVA
Dependent variable: Mean of the subscale emotional awareness
Predictors: Time, frequency, interaction between time and frequency
II.	Daily emotional awareness 
a.	 Within person: increase of momentary emotional awareness over the period of 14 days
Analysis: A multilevel regression model will be used with measurements (momentary emotional awareness) at level 1 nested in days (level 2) nested in persons (level 3) . 
Dependent variable: Momentary emotional awareness
Predictor: Day number (level  2) 
Random effects: Random intercepts will be included at the person and day level; Random slope for day number at the person level.
b.	Between persons: higher increase in momentary emotional awareness with higher sampling frequency. 
Analysis: A multilevel regression model will be used with measurements ( momentary emotional awareness) at level 1 nested in days (level 2) and nested in person at level   3.
Dependent variable:  Momentary emotional awareness
Predictors: Frequency (at level   3); day number (at level   2); interaction of day number and frequency
Random effects: Random intercepts will be included at the person level and day level; Random slope for day number at the person level.

registration_responses.q1: Mariam Chichua, Gudrun Eisele, Peter Kuppens, Peter Kuppens
registration_responses.q2:
I.	Trait emotional awareness
a.	Within person: higher trait emotional awareness in the post-test compared to the pre-test
b.	Between persons: the increase between pre- and post-tests is bigger in higher sampling frequency groups
II.	Daily emotional awareness
a.	Within person: increase of momentary emotional awareness over the period of 14 days
b.	Between persons: higher increase in momentary emotional awareness with higher sampling frequency

attributes.title: Efficacy and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine for COVID- 19: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a global pandemic caused by the Severe
Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). The patients of COVID-19 usually present with fever, cough, while about 23.7% of patients are accompanied by at least one coexisting disease. The disease is highly contagious with a R0 value about 3-4. The rapid increase in the number of patients put great pressure on the health care system. With the aggravation of the shortage of medical treatment, the mortality rate of the disease increases. As of 15:00 on March 31, 2020, 793278 people were diagnosed with the disease and at least 38545 died.
At present, there is no specific cure for this disease, and the clinical management mainly depends on supportive treatment. Lopinavir-Ritonavir was once thought to be a promising medicine on COVID-19, but a recently published clinical trial found that the effect was limited. As excessive immune response is an important reason for the progression of the patient's condition, the researchers turned their attention to immunosuppressants. In a small sample clinical trial, the researchers found that Hydroxychloroquine could improve the state of patients' lungs and increase the probability of the virus turning negative. However, the sample size of this study is small, and there may be some defects in the research design. In a case report, Remdesivir has shown good efficacy in patients with COVID-19, and larger clinical trials are currently under way. Therefore, it is an important and urgent task to explore new therapeutic agents.
In the fourth edition of the diagnosis and treatment guideline of COVID-19 in China, Lianhuaqingwen capsule was listed as one of the recommended medicines. In addition, traditional Chinese medicines (CHM), including Qingfei Paidu decoction, Huanglian Jiedu decoction etc., are also widely used in the adjuvant treatment of COVID-19. In terms of clinical research, many scholars have carried out clinical trials on the efficacy of CHM in treating COVID-19. However, these studies are only carried out in local areas, so they fail to provide definite evidence to prove the effectiveness of CHM. In this study, we aim to summarize the current evidence of CHM in treating COVID-19 through systematic review and meta-analysis. This study is necessary before further large-scale clinical studies being carried out. For clinicians, this study can provide some direction and guidance for clinical practice.

q2.value: This study aims to investigate the effects of Chinese herbal medicine in treating COVID-19.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) can provide evidence about efficacy of intervention, so they will be included in this systematic review. However, the outbreak of COVID-19 is an urgent public health event, and it is difficult to carry out RCTs, so non-randomized controlled trials will also be included in this study, although non-randomized controlled trials (non-RCTs) may be more biased than RCTs.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Three English database including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library Central Register of Controlled Trials and four Chinese databases including China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) database, Wanfang Data Knowledge Service Platform, the VIP information resource integration service platform (cqvip), China Biology Medicine Disc (Sino Med) will be searched from its inception to April 1, 2020 without language limitation. Preprinted website including arXiv (http://arxiv.org/), BioRxiv (https://www.biorxiv.org/), F1000 (https://f1000.com/) and PeerJ Preprints (https://peerj.com/preprints/) will also be searched to find out more unpublished papers. In addition, Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR) and ClinicalTrials.gov will also be searched to find out ongoing research. 
A search strategy of the combination of controlled vocabulary and text words will be adopted. Boolean operators will be used to concatenate search terms. This work will be conducted by two authors ( Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) independently.
EndNote X9 will be used by two researchers (Zhipeng Hu and Maoyi Yang) to screen the citations independently according to the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Discrepancies between two authors will be solved by discussion with a third author (Rensong Yue).

q11.value: There will be no limitation about sample size.

question.value: Since there are no core outcome sets for COVID-19, it is difficult to predefined what outcomes will be included in our study. In general, any outcome that can reflect the condition will be included in this study.

Data analysis will be conducted using Stata 14.0 software. The effect measure of binary variable will be expressed as risk ratio (RR) or odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval (CI). For continuous variables, 95% CI and mean difference (MD) or standardized mean difference (SMD) will be used. The number needed to treat (NNT) will be calculated for the interpretation of results. Cochrane X2 and I2 tests will be conducted to assess the heterogeneity analysis between studies. When P < .05 and I2>50%, a random effect model will be used. When P > .05 and I2<50%, then a fixed effect model will be used to calculate the effect size. The results of RCTs and non-RCTs will be analyzed and presented independently. Subgroup analysis will be conducted to explore the subgroup effects and investigate the source of heterogeneity. If there is a substantial heterogeneity and quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, the results will be presented in the form of tables and figures. 
Publication bias and small-study effects will be evaluated by funnel plot and statistically investigated by Egger’s test with a P value boundary of .05.

attributes.title: Efficacy and Safety of Chinese Herbal Medicine for COVID- 19: a protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a global pandemic caused by the Severe
Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2). The patients of COVID-19 usually present with fever, cough, while about 23.7% of patients are accompanied by at least one coexisting disease. The disease is highly contagious with a R0 value about 3-4. The rapid increase in the number of patients put great pressure on the health care system. With the aggravation of the shortage of medical treatment, the mortality rate of the disease increases. As of 15:00 on March 31, 2020, 793278 people were diagnosed with the disease and at least 38545 died.
At present, there is no specific cure for this disease, and the clinical management mainly depends on supportive treatment. Lopinavir-Ritonavir was once thought to be a promising medicine on COVID-19, but a recently published clinical trial found that the effect was limited. As excessive immune response is an important reason for the progression of the patient's condition, the researchers turned their attention to immunosuppressants. In a small sample clinical trial, the researchers found that Hydroxychloroquine could improve the state of patients' lungs and increase the probability of the virus turning negative [12]. However, the sample size of this study is small, and there may be some defects in the research design. In a case report, Remdesivir has shown good efficacy in patients with COVID-19, and larger clinical trials are currently under way. Therefore, it is an important and urgent task to explore new therapeutic agents.
In the fourth edition of the diagnosis and treatment guideline of COVID-19 in China, Lianhuaqingwen capsule was listed as one of the recommended medicines. In addition, traditional Chinese medicines (CHM), including Qingfei Paidu decoction, Huanglian Jiedu decoction etc., are also widely used in the adjuvant treatment of COVID-19. In terms of clinical research, many scholars have carried out clinical trials on the efficacy of CHM in treating COVID-19. However, these studies are only carried out in local areas, so they fail to provide definite evidence to prove the effectiveness of CHM. In this study, we aim to summarize the current evidence of CHM in treating COVID-19 through systematic review and meta-analysis. This study is necessary before further large-scale clinical studies being carried out. For clinicians, this study can provide some direction and guidance for clinical practice.

attributes.title: conspiracy theory endorsement and panic buying/stockpiling
attributes.description: This study investigates the association between endorsement for COVID-19 related conspiracy

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value:
To test the first hypothesis, a linear regression will be conducted where conspiracy endorsement is used to predict panic buying scale. The second model will in addition include a term for income and its interaction with conspiracy endorsement scale.

, with gender, age, education, income, need for cognition, and perception that COVID-19 is a real threat as covariates.

dependent.value:
It is a scale consists of the following items begin with the instruction "Since the outbreak of COVID-19, to what degree have you been stockpiling the following categories of items?"
1. shelf stable food (e.g., canned food, dry pasta)
2. Fresh produce (e.g., fresh fruit, vegetables, and eggs)
3. Weaponry (e.g., guns, bullets, knives)
4. Toilet paper
5. Sanitizing products (e.g., disinfectant wipes, Purell)
6. Substances (e.g., alcohol and cigarettes)

1=Not at all, 5 =As much as you can

conditions.value: This study is correlational and there is only one condition

hypothesis.value:
H1 Endorsement of conspiracy about the COVID-19 is related to panic buying (i.e., stockpiling goods)
H2 the relationship is stronger for people with more income

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

, with gender, age, education, income, need for cognition, and perception that COVID-19 is a real threat as covariates.

attributes.title: Is Hidradenitis Suppurativa associated with a lower socioeconomic status compared to the general population: A systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description:
1. * Review title.
Is Hidradenitis Suppurativa associated with a lower socioeconomic status compared to the general population: A systematic review and meta-analysis.

2. * Anticipated or actual start date.
05/02/2020

3. * Anticipated completion date.
07/04/2020

4. * Stage of review at time of this submission.
Review stage	Started	Completed
Preliminary searches	Completed	
Piloting of the study selection process	Completed	
Formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria	Completed		

5. * Named contact.
Adrian Bailey

6. * Named contact email.
abail082@uottawa.ca

7. Named contact address
4512 Appleton Side Road

8. Named contact phone number.
6138585029

9. * Organisational affiliation of the review.
University of Ottawa


10. * Funding sources/sponsors.
None


11. * Conflicts of interest.
None


12. * Review question.
Is Hidradenitis Suppurativa associated with a lower socioeconomic status compared to the general population?

P = Adult patients with Hidradenitis Suppurativa
I = N/A
C = The general adult population (or a reference population that is representative of the general population)
O = Socioeconomic status

13. * Searches.
PubMed and Scopus (April 3rd 2020). No date restrictions. English articles only.

14. * Condition or domain being studied.

Low socioeconomic status (SES) has been shown to be associated with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS); however, the literature lacks an assessment of this association across a variety of populations and recommendations for future research. Here, we plan toi systematically review and meta-analyse the current evidence on HS and SES.

15. * Participants/population.
Inclusion:
-Adult patients (16 years or older) with Hidradenitis Suppurativa

Exclusion:
-Paediatric patients
-Animal studies

16. * Intervention(s), exposure(s).
-Not applicable.

17. * Comparator(s)/control.
-General population (ex. other dermatology patients)

18. * Types of study to be included.
Eligible study designs included population-based retrospective cohort, cross sectional, and case-control studies. Grey literature and other study designs were excluded.

An Odds ratio will be used to measure the association between low socioeconomic status and patients with Hidradenitis Suppurativa compared to a reference population (a representative sample of the general population). Studies that do not provide this data, data necessary to calculate an Odds ratio, or their corresponding author was not able to provide this data will be excluded.

19. * Main outcome(s).
-Socioeconomic status. Any definition and stratification of SES will be accepted, such as income, postal code, occupation, insurance status, and census data.

* Measures of effect
-An Odds ratio will be used to measure the association between low socioeconomic status and patients with Hidradenitis Suppurativa compared to a reference population.

20. * Data extraction (selection and coding).
-Study Characteristics = setting, date range of data collection, population size, socioeconomic status measure used, if an adjusted model was used, and what factors were accounted for if an adjusted model was used.
-Odds ratio or raw data that can be used to calculate the Odds ratio of the association of low socioeconomic status and patients with Hidradenitis Suppurativa, compared to a reference population.

21. * Risk of bias (quality) assessment.
The risk of bias will be determined using the National Institutes of Health Quality Assessment Tool for Observational Cohort and Cross-Sectional Studies.

22. * Strategy for data synthesis.
The inverse variance model with the fixed effects model, to account for variations in study size, will be used to estimate the Odds ratio and confidence intervals for each study. Heterogeneity across studies will be assessed using the I² statistic.

23. * Analysis of subgroups or subsets.
None planned

24. Language.
English

25. * Country.
Canada

26. Dissemination plans.
Publication to a major journal.

27. Current review status.
Ongoing.

summary.value:
Low socioeconomic status (SES) has been shown to be associated with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS); however, the literature lacks an assessment of this association across a variety of populations and recommendations for future research. Here, we plan toi systematically review and meta-analyse the current evidence on HS and SES.

Please refer to attached file for study protocol.

registration_responses.summary:
Low socioeconomic status (SES) has been shown to be associated with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS); however, the literature lacks an assessment of this association across a variety of populations and recommendations for future research. Here, we plan toi systematically review and meta-analyse the current evidence on HS and SES.

Please refer to attached file for study protocol.

Here, we systematically review and meta-analyse the current evidence on HS and SES.

attributes.title: Online supplementary material for "Views on social media and its linkage to longitudinal data from two generations of a UK cohort study"
attributes.description:
Repository of supplementary materials from the above project. These are:
1. Powerpoint presentation slides from focus group. 
2. CORE-Q checklist

summary.value: This project contains the supplementary material for "Views on social media and its linkage to longitudinal data from two generations of a UK cohort study". These materials are the powerpoint presentation slides used during the focus groups, as well as the Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Studies (COREQ) checklist.

registration_responses.summary: This project contains the supplementary material for "Views on social media and its linkage to longitudinal data from two generations of a UK cohort study". These materials are the powerpoint presentation slides used during the focus groups, as well as the Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Studies (COREQ) checklist.

attributes.title: Efficacy of homemade masks to prevent virus droplet infection : Rapid systematic review
attributes.description:
Objective: To identify, evaluate and summarise the best available scientific evidence on the efficacy and safety of homemade masks for the community.
Research question: What is the effect of the homemade masks to protect the comunity from virus droplets infection?
Method: Rapid systematic review.
Inclusion criteria: articles that verified the efficacy of homemade masks to protect against the virus transmission.  
Exclusion criteria: articles involving the use of masks by the health care professionals 
The following electronic bibliographic databases will be searched: Cochrane Library (via Wiley); Embase (via Elsevier); LILACS; Medical Literature Analysis and Retrieval System Online MEDLINE, via PubMed) and Opengrey ( https://opengrey.eu). 
The terms MeSH were “infection”, “prevention”, “masks”, “Respiratory Protective Devices”, “society”
The search will not have limit of year of publication or language.
Two independente evaluators will select the studies and a third evaluator will be consulted in case of disagreements. The GRADE approach will be used to assess the methodological quality.

summary.value: This is a rapid systematic review to identify the articles that verified the efficacy of homemade masks to protect against the virus transmission.

registration_responses.summary: This is a rapid systematic review to identify the articles that verified the efficacy of homemade masks to protect against the virus transmission.

attributes.title: Trolls Psyc 2017
attributes.description:
The Dark Tetrad is made up of four different personalities: Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. We encounter these personalities every day; the Machiavellian who has tricked you into giving something up, the narcissist who constantly brags about themselves, the subclinical psychopath who has physically hurt you, and the sadist who hurts people for fun. Cyberbullying is prominent in today’s society, as well as other online behaviors such as trolling. Trolling involves being deceptive online for no reason and towards people the person doesn’t know, and tricking people into humiliating themselves (Buckels, Trapnell, & Paulhus, 2014). Online trolls are individuals who partake in deceptive, destructive, or disruptive behavior in a social setting on the Internet with no apparent instrumental purpose (Buckels, Trapnell & Paulhus, 2014). There are many possible predictors of social media trolling behavior, specifically psychosocial disorders. As these individuals have no apparent purpose, we need an explanation for the behavior displayed by these online trolls is searched for. With research, one can gain an understanding of these behaviors. To begin to conduct research in order to understand trolling behaviors, one has to understand why these behaviors are prevalent in certain individuals. Research also indicates that those who are narcissists and those with antisocial personality disorder use social media more often than others (Rosen, Whaling, Rab, Carrier & Cheever, 2013). An online “troll” is a separate personality related entity, and in order to understand this identity, one must understand the self- presentation that’s goes into its construction (Fox & Rooney, 2015).
The behavior displayed by trolls over the Internet can not only give a lot of insight into the psychosocial disorders an individual may or may not possess or develop, but can also have severe effects on the individual on the receiving end of the trolls’ malicious behavior. By understanding the psychosocial predictors of social media trolling, the online behavior may be prevented along with its substantial and negative consequences to its victims (Howard, Zolnierek, Critz, Dailey & Ceballos, 2019). There is a relationship believed to be between the Big Five personality traits, Dark Triad traits, and sadism with bullying and/ or cyberbullying (van Geel, Goemans, Toprak & Vedder, 2017).If there is a relation between theses personality disorders and cyberbullying, as well as with increased social media use, then the negative behavior of online trolls can be predicted and prevented. This would solve the issue of the negative consequences trolling can have, while addressing the psychosocial disorder the ‘troll’ is experiencing. Understanding the meaning of an online “troll” and what traits they possess can also help society establish constructs of identity, as traits from the Dark Triad can manifest in both trolls and victims (Linton & Power, 2013).

q1.value: Negative Social Media Interactions and the Dark Tetrad

q2.value: Ashley Evans, Katie Gatewood, Tai Lambert

q3.value:
The Dark Tetrad is made up of four different personalities: Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. We encounter these personalities every day; the Machiavellian who has tricked you into giving something up, the narcissist who constantly brags about themselves, the subclinical psychopath who has physically hurt you, and the sadist who hurts people for fun. Cyberbullying is prominent in today’s society, as well as other online behaviors such as trolling. Trolling involves being deceptive online for no reason and towards people the person doesn’t know, and tricking people into humiliating themselves (Buckels, Trapnell, & Paulhus, 2014). Online trolls are individuals who partake in deceptive, destructive, or disruptive behavior in a social setting on the Internet with no apparent instrumental purpose (Buckels, Trapnell & Paulhus, 2014). There are many possible predictors of social media trolling behavior, specifically psychosocial disorders. As these individuals have no apparent purpose, we need an explanation for the behavior displayed by these online trolls is searched for. With research, one can gain an understanding of these behaviors. To begin to conduct research in order to understand trolling behaviors, one has to understand why these behaviors are prevalent in certain individuals. Research also indicates that those who are narcissists and those with antisocial personality disorder use social media more often than others (Rosen, Whaling, Rab, Carrier & Cheever, 2013). An online “troll” is a separate personality related entity, and in order to understand this identity, one must understand the self- presentation that’s goes into its construction (Fox & Rooney, 2015).

 

The behavior displayed by trolls over the Internet can not only give a lot of insight into the psychosocial disorders an individual may or may not possess or develop, but can also have severe effects on the individual on the receiving end of the trolls’ malicious behavior. By understanding the psychosocial predictors of social media trolling, the online behavior may be prevented along with its substantial and negative consequences to its victims (Howard, Zolnierek, Critz, Dailey & Ceballos, 2019). There is a relationship believed to be between the Big Five personality traits, Dark Triad traits, and sadism with bullying and/ or cyberbullying (van Geel, Goemans, Toprak & Vedder, 2017).If there is a relation between theses personality disorders and cyberbullying, as well as with increased social media use, then the negative behavior of online trolls can be predicted and prevented. This would solve the issue of the negative consequences trolling can have, while addressing the psychosocial disorder the ‘troll’ is experiencing. Understanding the meaning of an online “troll” and what traits they possess can also help society establish constructs of identity, as traits from the Dark Triad can manifest in both trolls and victims (Linton & Power, 2013).

q4.value: Individuals who participate more in negative social media interactions are more likely to possess or develop the personality disorders which make up the Dark Tetrad. The hypothesis is directional with a positive relationship between negative social media interactions and personality disorders within the Dark Tetrad.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study encompasses trait comparisons with a single group using Pearson correlations to determine how negative online social media interactions predict the possession of personality traits within the Dark Tetrad.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Two large samples of participants will be recruited from the US on Amazon's Mechanical Turk website (MTurk; http://www.mturk.com) and students from a psychology department at a University in Canada. Participants are to be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk Website will receive $.50 in compensation for their time and the participating Canadian psychology students will receive extra credit for their participation in the study.

q13.value: We will collect two large samples online. The first sample will be from a pool of Canadian psychology students with a target size of 188. The second sample will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk website (MTurk; http.//www.mturk.com) with a target size of 609.

q15.value: Stopping rule will not be applied, no sequential analysis will be used in the sampling process

question.value: Variables that will be measured include extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, openness, narcissism, Machiavellianism, sub-clinical psychopathy, sadism, direct physical sadism, direct verbal sadism, vicarious sadism, hours spent per day on the internet, commenting frequency, enjoyment of debating, chatting, trolling and making friends, and trolling tendencies.

To analyze our results we will run Pearson correlations between personality traits, commenting frequency, and enjoyment of specified activities. We will also run a Pearson correlation between personality traits and commenting frequency while controlling for overall internet use.

q21.value: Each analyses will be a two-tailed test. We will use the criterion of p>.05, p>.01, and p>.001. When comparing multiple conditions, we will run regression analyses and mediation analyses.

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis, and a separate analyses without the outlier will also be conducted in order to compare the two outcomes. An explanation will be provided as to why any data would be considered an outlier and the difference that removing the outlier makes in the outcome.

q23.value: If a subject does not answer all of the questions, the subject's data will not be included in the analysis.

q25.value: We will be replicating the study of Buckels, E. E., et al. Trolls just want to have fun. Personality and Individual Differences (2014), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2014.01.016

registration_responses.q1: Negative Social Media Interactions and the Dark Tetrad
registration_responses.q2: Ashley Evans, Katie Gatewood, Tai Lambert
registration_responses.q3:
The Dark Tetrad is made up of four different personalities: Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. We encounter these personalities every day; the Machiavellian who has tricked you into giving something up, the narcissist who constantly brags about themselves, the subclinical psychopath who has physically hurt you, and the sadist who hurts people for fun. Cyberbullying is prominent in today’s society, as well as other online behaviors such as trolling. Trolling involves being deceptive online for no reason and towards people the person doesn’t know, and tricking people into humiliating themselves (Buckels, Trapnell, & Paulhus, 2014). Online trolls are individuals who partake in deceptive, destructive, or disruptive behavior in a social setting on the Internet with no apparent instrumental purpose (Buckels, Trapnell & Paulhus, 2014). There are many possible predictors of social media trolling behavior, specifically psychosocial disorders. As these individuals have no apparent purpose, we need an explanation for the behavior displayed by these online trolls is searched for. With research, one can gain an understanding of these behaviors. To begin to conduct research in order to understand trolling behaviors, one has to understand why these behaviors are prevalent in certain individuals. Research also indicates that those who are narcissists and those with antisocial personality disorder use social media more often than others (Rosen, Whaling, Rab, Carrier & Cheever, 2013). An online “troll” is a separate personality related entity, and in order to understand this identity, one must understand the self- presentation that’s goes into its construction (Fox & Rooney, 2015).

 

The behavior displayed by trolls over the Internet can not only give a lot of insight into the psychosocial disorders an individual may or may not possess or develop, but can also have severe effects on the individual on the receiving end of the trolls’ malicious behavior. By understanding the psychosocial predictors of social media trolling, the online behavior may be prevented along with its substantial and negative consequences to its victims (Howard, Zolnierek, Critz, Dailey & Ceballos, 2019). There is a relationship believed to be between the Big Five personality traits, Dark Triad traits, and sadism with bullying and/ or cyberbullying (van Geel, Goemans, Toprak & Vedder, 2017).If there is a relation between theses personality disorders and cyberbullying, as well as with increased social media use, then the negative behavior of online trolls can be predicted and prevented. This would solve the issue of the negative consequences trolling can have, while addressing the psychosocial disorder the ‘troll’ is experiencing. Understanding the meaning of an online “troll” and what traits they possess can also help society establish constructs of identity, as traits from the Dark Triad can manifest in both trolls and victims (Linton & Power, 2013).

The hypothesis is directional with a positive relationship between negative social media interactions and personality disorders within the Dark Tetrad.

attributes.title: The awareness of women on Prostate cancer: A mixed methods systematic review.
attributes.description: A systematic review aimed at mapping up evidence from qualitative and quantitative studies that assessed the awareness of women on prostate cancer.

summary.value: This project is mainly a mixed methods systematic review which will collect data from both qualitative and quantitative studies that assessed the knowledge/awareness of women on the signs and symptoms; and causes/risk factors of prostate cancer and the available screening recommendations for the early detection of prostate cancer. The Joanna Briggs manual will guide the conduct of this review.

registration_responses.summary: This project is mainly a mixed methods systematic review which will collect data from both qualitative and quantitative studies that assessed the knowledge/awareness of women on the signs and symptoms; and causes/risk factors of prostate cancer and the available screening recommendations for the early detection of prostate cancer. The Joanna Briggs manual will guide the conduct of this review.
